    Autoencoder Anomaly Detection

    Contents

    • Overview
    • Time series Embedding with Reservoir Computing
    • Model Architecture and training
    • Results
      • Lyngen
      • Nordnes
      • Svalbard
    • Limitations

    Overview

    This report documents a reconstruction-based anomaly detector trained on regularly sampled InSAR time series. The intuition is that an autoencoder will map the majority of the data to a compact latent space. Under the assumption that anomalous data are rare, these will not live in the same manifold in the latent space and, thus, when projected there will yield a high reconstruction error when decoded back. Such a reconstruction error can be used to determine which data point is anomalous and which is not.

    Time series Embedding with Reservoir Computing

    As discussed in the RANSAC section, the time series are first pre-processed by filling the missing months with the RANSAC interpolant.

    Afterwards, the time series are converted into static vectors using Reservoir Computing. The basic idea is that an untrained recurrent architectures, the Reservoir, processes the time series and returns a vectorial representation containing all the dynamical features of the time series.

    The vectorial representation can be, for example, the last state of the Reservoir’s states, a set of linear weights used to predict the next output or the next Reservoir’s state. For more information about time series embeddings with RC, see here.

    Model Architecture and training

    We use a symmetric fully connected encoder/decoder with bottleneck dimension.

    architecture:
  name: Simple-AE
  type: AutoEncoder
  hparams:
    encoder_dims: [32, 16, 8, 4]
    decoder_dims: [8, 16, 32]
    activation: "ReLU"
    batch_norm: True
    dropout: 0.1

    The model is trained to minimize the mse.

    The input are the Reservoir embeddings without the static features.

    Results

    Dataset Train MAE Test MAE
    Lyngen 0.108 0.109
    Nordnes 0.108 0.109
    Svalbard 0.084 0.085

    Lyngen

    Below, we plot the reconstruction error for each data point.

    Then, we select the points with the top $2.5\%$ reconstruction error and we plot them as triangles. The color-coding is given by the mean velocity of each time series.

    Nordnes

    Svalbard

    Limitations

    • No relational/spatial information is considered.
    • Time series embedding is unsupervised and occur in a preprocessing step, which is agnostic of the downstream task (i.e., the AE reconstruction).

    Updated: October 9, 2025
